title: Measuring Series Circuits (advanced)

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: Use the DMM to measure the circuit above.

subquestions.prompt: What is the voltage dropped across all the resistors?

options.option: 9 V
options.feedback: Right! The circuit voltage is measured across all three resistors.

subquestions.prompt: What is the current flowing through the circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS =9/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Right! The same current passes through all the resistors in a series circuit.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R1+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R1+R2); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R1/(R1+R2+R3)/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R2/(R1+R2+R3)/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R3/(R1+R2+R3)/99; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R1+R2+R3)*(1.03+0.03*Math.random()); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R1+R2+R3)*(0.97-0.03*Math.random()); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in current mode, break the circuit by lifting a lead, and insert the leads into the break. See the tutorial for more help.

subquestions.prompt: What is the actual total resistance value for this circuit?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = R1+R2+R3; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Right! Using Ohm's Law with your measurements you found the actual total resistance of this circuit.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var ANS = R1; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R2 = r2.resistance; var ANS = R2; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = R3; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! You calculated the value for just one resistor. To calculate the resistance for all the resistors you use the total voltage and the total current. If you're unsure about this, check the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9/(R1+R2+R3)*Math.pow(10,3+Math.floor(Math.log10(R1+R2+R3))); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Are you guessing? This is similar to the value for the current in the circuit. You need to calculate the resistance using the circuit voltage and the current. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = (R1+R2+R3)*(1.03+0.03*Math.random()); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Did you make a calculation error? This is close to the correct resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = (R1+R2+R3)*(0.97-0.03*Math.random()); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Did you make a calculation error? This is close to the correct resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

options.option: [var R1=r1.resistance; var R2=r2.resistance; var R3=r3.resistance; var nR1=r1.nominalResistance; var nR2=r2.nominalResistance; var nR3=r3.nominalResistance; RTOT=Math.toSigFigs(R1+R2+R3,3); nRTOT=Math.toSigFigs(nR1+nR2+nR3,3); if (RTOT==nRTOT) {ANS=nRTOT*1.02;} else {ANS=nRTOT;}; ANS] ohms
options.feedback: Isn't this just the sum of the labeled R values? You need to measure the circuit to find to the actual circuit resistance. See the tutorial if you're unsure.

pages.notes:
The actual resistances of each resistor may differ from its labeled value.

Unfortunately, the resistance function on your meter is broken, so you can only measure voltage and current.

questions.prompt: For the resistors in the breadboard circuit above, use the DMM to measure the voltages across each and the current through each.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R1/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Right! This is the voltage measured across resistor R1.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R1/(R1+R2+R3)*(10.1+Math.random()/10); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! Did you misread the knob setting on the DMM? You have almost the right digits, but the wrong decimal point location.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R2/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! Were the probes placed across R1 when you measured that voltage? If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R3/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Oops! Were the probes placed across R1 when you measured that voltage? If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R1+R2)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Did you accidentally measure across two resistors? You need to place the DMM probes on either end of R1 to measure this voltage. If unsure about this, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*(R2+R3)/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Did you accidentally measure across two resistors? You need to place the DMM probes on either end of R1 to measure this voltage. If unsure about this, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; ANS=9*R1/(R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] V
options.feedback: Oops! Did you actually measure this value? If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance;ANS=9/(R1+R2+R3)/(2+Math.floor(Math.random()*5)); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] V
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across R1. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [ANS=9/(2+Math.floor(Math.random()*5)); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] V
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across R1. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [ANS=9*(1.01+Math.random()*.09); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] V
options.feedback: Are you guessing? This is greater than the voltage across the whole circuit. You need to place the probes just across R1 to measure the voltage dropped across that resistor. If unsure about this, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; ANS=9/(R1+R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] A
options.feedback: Right! The current through the whole circuit passes through this series resistor.

options.option: [var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; ANS=9/(R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; ANS=9/(R1+R3); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; ANS=9/(R1+R2); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] A
options.feedback: You must measure current differently than voltage: lift a lead to break the circuit, insert the DMM probes into the break, and then measure the current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R1/(R1+R2+R3)/100; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: This value appears to be perhaps a voltage measurement, not a current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.feedback: This value appears to be perhaps a voltage measurement, not a current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.feedback: This value appears to be perhaps a voltage measurement, not a current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across R1. See the tutorial for more help.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R2/(R1+R2+R3); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V
options.feedback: Right! This is the voltage measured across resistor R2.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R2/(R1+R2+R3)*(10.1+Math.random()/10); var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] V

options.feedback: Did you accidentally measure across two resistors? You need to place the DMM probes on either end of R2 to measure this voltage. If unsure about this, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = 9*R3/(R1+R2+R3)/100; var numDigits = 3; if (Math.floor(ANS/Math.powNdigits(ANS,1)) == 1) {numDigits = 4}; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,numDigits)] A
options.feedback: This value appears to be perhaps a voltage measurement, not a current. If unsure, check out the tutorial.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance;ANS=9/(R1+R2+R3)/(2+Math.floor(Math.random()*5)); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] A
options.feedback: Are you guessing? You need to use the DMM in voltage mode to measure the voltage across R1. See the tutorial for more help.

questions.prompt: What are the actual resistance values for each resistor?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; Math.toSigFigs(R1,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Right! You correctly calculated the resistance of R1.

options.option: [var R2 = r2.resistance; Math.toSigFigs(R2,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! Did you accidentally select the value for another resistor?

options.option: [var R3 = r3.resistance; Math.toSigFigs(R3,3)] ohms
options.feedback: Oops! Did you accidentally select the value for another resistor?

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = R1+R2+R3; Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: That's the total resistance of all the resistors, rather than just R1. See the tutorial for more explanation.

options.option: [var R1 = r1.resistance; var R2 = r2.resistance; var R3 = r3.resistance; var ANS = R1*(R2+R3)/(R1+R2+R3); Math.toSigFigs(ANS,3)] ohms
options.feedback: It seems you're using a wrong current value to make your calculation. See the tutorial if you're unsure.
